speechtext: The House resumed from Friday, May 15 consideration of the motion of Mr. Benjamin (p. 10825).

speakeroldname: Ms. Nicole Roy-Arcelin (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of Communications):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Communications
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the motion concerns the inability of municipal infrastructures to meet the current needs of Canadians with respect to water treatment and supply and to respond to their concerns about the environment and about threats to public health.
Infrastructures must be improved, expanded and modernized. This is indeed a tall order. To do so, it will be necessary to invest billions of dollars and to determine where the money should come from, which will not be easy, considering the economic situation all governments are facing today.
One point that should be made is the fact that water demand in municipalities is unlimited because there is no appropriate control system and no commensurate billing for this resource. Even if we did have commensurate rates without meters the many people who are connected to municipal water systems have no idea of the level of their water consumption.
Installing meters is essential for water conservation and to ensure this resource does not run out. All homes have meters for hydro and gas and most of the services we purchase are measured by weight and volume. A
supplier wants to know how much of his product is consumed and users should be able to check their consumption.
The federal government's responsibility for conservation and sustainable development of our water supply is limited to encouraging proper management of the resource and an appreciation of its value. Providing water meters or financing their purchase and installation is not a federal responsibility.
As was pointed out by my colleague, the hon. member for Regina-Lumsden, only 50 per cent of connections to public water mains in Canada have meters. Installing meters across the country would be the first essential step of any nation-wide program to renew Canadian municipal infrastructures. Without the ability to measure water consumption one cannot think of implementing a realistic rate structure to recover the full cost from the user.
Can we think of another multi-billion dollar industry that does not measure the usage of its main product? Can we imagine stopping at a filling station and paying the same price no matter the amount of gasoline desired? It is unthinkable.
Since measuring water consumption is of the utmost importance for recovering the full cost and setting a realistic rate structure and therefore is very important for municipal infrastructure, the minister will look carefully into the measurement of water consumption in order to see whether water meters should be installed in all Canadian municipalities and what benefits would flow from such action. The minister will first consider the current situation in Canada as far as water measurement is concerned and then discuss the costs and benefits.
In Canada only about half the public water service connections are metered. Furthermore, the smaller the community, the less likely it is to measure consumption, although consumption is not measured in large areas of some of the biggest cities, such as Calgary Toronto and Vancouver.

In cities where some connections are metered, 72 per cent of industrial use, 67 per cent of commercial use and only 31 per cent of domestic use are measured. This situation clearly works against any attempt to set prices for municipal water services that reflect their true value. It just cannot be done under such conditions.
Theoretically, consumers are as free to waste water when consumption is measured as when it is not. However, actual experience shows that the opposite happens. Volumes vary greatly between regions where consumption is measured and those where it is not. Households consume between 0.5 and 0.7 cubic metres per day where it is measured and 1.3 cubic metres per day where it is not. This is a universal phenomenon. This difference is due to the drop in consumption, often as much as 25 per cent, after meters are installed and users are charged on the basis of volume consumed.
We should understand that this drop in consumption does not follow an increase in unit cost but is because customers pay for each unit consumed. In Canada the prairies are far ahead of the other provinces in metering consumption. More than 70 per cent of prairie municipalities measure the consumption of all users and only 12 per cent do not measure it at all. By contrast less than 18 per cent of the cities and towns in British Columbia, Quebec, New Brunswick and Newfoundland and from 25 to 50 per cent of those in the other provinces measure what they consume.
We can thus conclude that much remains to be done before all Canadian municipalities adopt the principle of measuring water consumption. At $200 per connection it would cost nearly $800 million for equipment and installation to have water meters throughout the country. This is a small one-time expense to control the demand of an industry that brings in $3 billion a year.
Given the debate on water metering in many regions of the country and the size of the expenses involved, we must look into the costs and benefits. Several economic principles underlie the evaluation of water metering. As a general rule when the costs and benefits are thoroughly analyzed to judge the impact of metering on all water systems, including sewage treatment, municipalities find that the benefits far outweigh the costs, which are quickly recovered.
Many cities throughout the world have studied this issue and many very diverse studies are available. These give us a general idea of the economic costs and benefits of metering.
The Science Council of Canada examined the costs and benefits of water metering as part of the water guidelines it is considering for the future. According to one of these basic studies metering is cost-effective if water costs more than 21 cents a cubic metre and installing a meter costs less than $500. These two preconditions are met in most Canadian municipalities.
A 1984 report from the State of California shows that it costs only $80 to install a meter when a house is built.
A 1972 study in the Toronto area reported the results of a simulation of the costs and benefits of metering for the municipality of Etobicoke. Data taken from the simulation show a cost-benefit ratio of 1:1, indicating that metering is economically viable.
A 1980 Alberta environment study dealt with measuring water consumption in cities where water collection, treatment and distribution are centralized. The net benefit, after including all costs, was $29.47 per capita which means that metering is economically advantageous.
A study done in Perth, Australia, on ways to restrict access to water resources calculated the benefits each month instead of at the end of the year as is usually the case. The study produced a cost benefit ratio of 1:62, which again shows that metering makes good economic sense. We can therefore say with almost complete certainty that water metering saves money, not to mention the operational savings for the industry that supplies and treats water.
As well as being cost effective, water metering, combined with an effective rate structure, leads to a sharp drop in consumption. This drop is partly due to the psychological impact of metering, since consumers know that they can reduce their water bills. However, the reduction is also due to an economic factor, namely the rationalization of water consumption since users pay more the more they consume once the meters are installed.
Therefore, installing meters nationwide is an essential first step to restructuring the water industry in Canada in order to make it financially and environmentally viable. The studies done on metering have shown that it pays off. Water meters and realistic rates to recover the full

operating cost can lead to a 30 per cent drop in demand and eliminate the need to increase system capacity.

Mr. Speaker, it is my privilege to support the motion relating to the infrastructure program.
It is important to note that all municipalities and provincial governments have tried to impress upon this government a number of things. First, the state of the infrastructure in this country demands immediate attention. Second, all three levels of government are prepared to work co-operatively and in concert with one another. All levels of government want to put the taxpayers' dollars into a combined effort and pool to invest in our infrastructure. This kind of a program is absolutely essential.
If one looks at the unemployment rate, especially in the construction industry throughout the country, one sees that this infrastructure program is not a frill, is not something we can postpone and do 10 or 15 years down the road. It needs to be done now.
There are good reasons to do it now. Interest rate costs and competitive opportunities now exist and municipalities could get good competitive bids to do water works, sewers, sidewalks, water plants, all the kinds of things we have acknowledged are very important to the quality of our lives.
If we truly believe in the environment, if we truly believe infrastructure is an investment in our people, in our neighbourhoods, in our communities, in people in terms of jobs, then there is no reason for us not to proceed.
I know the government is considering an infrastructure program. In its discussions with the provinces it has talked about highways. The provincial governments as well as the municipalities through their federation of Canadian municipalities have tried to convince the government of these priorities. It is not as if Canada and former governments have not participated in municipal infrastructure programs. In fact they were in place until 1984 when this present government came in and decided that it wanted to have absolutely nothing to do with investing in municipal and urban programs.
Private Members' Business
The precedent for a federal government to be involved in such a program is there. Canada has always done it. The federal government has always done it. All provincial premiers are prepared to put their taxpayers' dollars on the table. Every municipality is prepared to put every taxpayer's dollar on the table.
The Liberal Party has suggested this program for a great many years and we even had an all-party committee look at the infrastructure programs. I am happy to say that the former minister of housing, the member for Don Valley East and the member for Oshawa from the NDP have supported calling on this government for municipal infrastructure programs.
For some members of the government to suggest it is probably not their business to get involved in infrastructure programs and municipal programs is a bunch of hog-wash. For the member opposite to suggest that the way to do these infrastructure programs is to increase the price to the consumer for water is absolutely shirking the responsibility government has to this whole country. That seems to be this government's tack all the time: Let us look to someone else to solve the unemployment problem. Let us look to someone else to solve the environment problem. Let us look to someone else to solve the infrastructure problem.
We have a unique opportunity here. It needs to be pursued. Even the American infrastructure is in a state of absolute disrepair and the new president-elect recognizes that they have to invest in the infrastructure. Investing in infrastructure will produce jobs.
For those who say it is easy to stand up here and talk about spending because the deficit will be increased, in study after study, the OECD study, the FCM study, economists have all indicated that for every dollar put into infrastructure not only will it cause employment, but it will also have a ripple effect. In fact the impact on the deficit, if any, will be negligible.
If governments at all levels decide to put up money the private sector will also put up money. So you are going to leverage private sector investment in the program and hence do even more.
I want to reiterate that the government has a responsibility and the responsibility is to put our people back to work. There is no reason for people in the construction industry and other people who have skills to be sitting at

home collecting unemployment and for those who have exhausted their unemployment benefits to now be receiving social assistance when in fact these programs are ready to be implemented tomorrow. FCM says there are municipalities prepared to start building those bridges, to start building those sewers, to start building those water plants, to start building those water lines tomorrow. That is how quickly it can happen.
It is not something we have to study over and over again. People are getting absolutely fed up with inaction. We need to put people back to work. TTiis is a unique opportunity and a unique program which will bring us all together, municipalities, provincial governments, the federal government, the private sector, labour, all working together to solve an infrastructure problem in this country, an environmental problem in this country, and a jobs problem in this country.
This is a unique opportunity and if this government had the guts and the vision to want to solve our problems in terms of joblessness and was serious about solving our problems with respect to the environment, this opportunity would not be missed.
Again I call on this government finally to show the people of Canada that it is prepared to move in a very positive way with the economy by bringing forward this program which I think has the approval and the consensus of most members of this House, the municipalities, the provinces, labour, and the private sector.
There is no reason to study it further. We can do it in a fiscally responsible way and get on with building and rebuilding this country from the infrastructure up and investing in people. That is what we have to do.

speakeroldname: Mr. Brian L. Gardiner (Prince George-Bulkley Valley):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, it is an important time, as other members have commented on, to talk about this particular motion before us today.
I want to congratulate the member of our caucus from Regina-Lumsden who has been pursuing this question of municipal infrastructure, planning and development for some time now. He is to be congratulated for having the foresight to have this motion brought before Parliament. It might be a bit of lucky timing on his part for this
motion to be the first item of business to be dealt with by this House upon our return.
It is important because there is a clear sense in the minds of Canadians right now that this government is adrift, that its conservative trickle-down policies, which were followed and were rejected by the American people in the last presidential election, pursued by the Conservative government are not working and it is clearly time for a change to seek new choices and to go in a new direction.
It is also very clear that this week, starting today, Canadians are expecting this House, and in particular the Prime Minister and the government, to say to Canadians exactly what it is that it is going to do to address the needs of the economy. The message that has been repeated perhaps ad nauseam following the referendum on October 26 is that now the referendum is out of the way at least for a short time that this government will turn its attention to the needs of the economy.
That has left a clear anticipation by Canadians that this week, perhaps starting today, we will hear from the government an economic outline of the plan that it is going to present to this House and to Canadians so that we can turn the economy around and get us out of the ditch the government has driven us into.
This motion gives the government an opportunity to do just that. It is a motion that calls on the House to join with provincial, municipal and regional governments to develop an infrastructure program that can help rebuild Canada.
One does not have to go very far to find out just how important it is to help rebuild our infrastructure. Just go to the front door of this building and see all of the work being done on the infrastructure for the House of Commons. The bus driver today said that they are digging up the water lines and the sewer lines. Yes, we probably need a big sewer line coming out of this place. If they can work on the infrastructure on Parliament Hill, certainly they can work on the infrastructure across Canada from coast to coast to coast.
What does infrastructure mean? Well it is clear to all of us who drive, who fly, who take our passenger rail service everywhere, that if we continue to ignore the work that must be done, the investment in our infra-

structure, we will then pay the price in ever greater amounts in the future.
To date this government has rejected out of hand any of those proposals though as of late we have heard hints from the Minister of Finance that he may consider an infrastructure program to tiy to kick-start the economy. I say one of the best infrastructure programs would be to scrap the GST. That would kick-start the economy.
What we need this government to do is to pay attention to those very details, the nitty-gritty parts of people's everyday lives. When they leave their houses in the morning, when they drive or take the bus to work, they know that their car or that bus is not going to be rattled to pieces because of holes in the pavement, that the bridges they drive across in this country are safe.
One of the best ways to address this infrastructure problem-and it is one that I have been working on myself in my riding and it is an issue that I share with my colleagues from Alberta, Saskatchewan and Manitoba- is the whole matter of highway upgrading and the question of the Yellowhead highway. Most people in western Canada are familiar with that particular highway, the northern Trans-Canada, as it is known to us in western Canada.
Sometimes it is just not fair. I wrote to the Minister of Transport recently. He wrote back telling me what this government is doing to help with highway construction in Atlantic Canada. I have nothing against the need to improve the roads in Atlantic Canada. This government is spending about $1.1 billion to help some of the provincial governments in Atlantic Canada rebuild some of the roads. Of course, there is much more work that needs to be done, but what about the Yellowhead highway?
Let us take a look at that. We used to have a program. The government says it cannot do this, that it has never done it before. Well in fact it was done before. We had a joint federal-provincial program called the Yellowhead Highway Improvement Program. It was a program between the federal and provincial governments in B.C. of $36 million and expired at the end of March 1990.
Private Members' Business
The new government, the Harcourt government in British Columbia and the transport minister there, Mr. Charbonneau, the member from Kamloops, fully support renewing that infrastructure program, the Yellowhead Highway Improvement Program. We have yet to get a signal or a message from this government that it will in fact endorse that program.
As the previous speaker mentioned, this is not something we have to study. We do not have to wait six months for a report to come in to tell us what we have to do. Those reports have been done. They are right and ready. I can tell you, Mr. Speaker, that if we called the village clerks in my riding and said that there was an infrastructure program ready to go and could they consider some projects that we could do, they would have those projects ready. They would be on the fax machine within minutes. We can do it.
The investment put into that will return to the public treasury in two ways. It is an investment we will eventually have to make in any event. If we do it now, it will save money. It will be cheaper to do now than to wait for years when it will cost considerably more. As well, estimates range. It has been said by some for example that for every $100 million we might invest in infrastructure the return to the public treasury in terms of taxation, money that we do not have to spend on UI and welfare that there is actually a net gain to the public treasury. That has been shown in a number of reports.
Unless it is keeping this as a big secret to be announced in a couple of weeks or so before an election campaign, why this government cannot seem to see that, is beyond me. I think most Canadians cannot understand this government's inaction on this issue as well.
In the short time I have left I appeal to this government to support this motion. I appeal to the Prime Minister to tell us today what this government is going to do when it comes to some economic direction. I ask for a little fairness. I ask that this government take a look at the kind of programs that can help communities, like the Yellowhead highway program that I am encouraging this government to sign because it is that kind of day-to-day bread and butter help that this government can provide to put Canadians to work. The government has a choice and that choice is for this infrastructure program. I encourage the government to support it.

speakeroldname: Mrs. Dorothy Dobbie (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of Consumer and Corporate Affairs and Minister of State (Agriculture)):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Consumer and Corporate Affairs; Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of State (Agriculture)
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I really wish it were that easy.
I am going to refer to my notes because I have a number of points I want to make, particularly with regard to the question of rail grade separations and its logical extension to rail safety.
As of January 1989 with the proclamation of the Railway Safety Act, the railways of this country have had their primary responsibility for safe rail practices clearly established and brought up to date. The federal Department of Transport monitors railway operations and it is empowered to take action to correct any threat to safety of the public or railway personnel.
Our two major railways, CN and CP Rail, had the best and the third-best safety records respectively, of all major North American railway companies in 1990.
However, this does not mean to say that there will be any reduction in the monitoring of their operations. The department has every intention of completely fulfilling its obligation to ensure that safe procedures are followed.
Despite the commendable goal put forth by the hon. member opposite, I feel that we can make the taxpayers' money go a lot further with a well thought out and balanced program of grade crossing improvements and public education than we can by assigning huge amounts of money to a comparatively few grade separation projects.
The reality is that Transport Canada's grade crossing improvement program provides an immediate safety dividend at a relatively low cost at many locations across Canada. For example, it takes approximately $80,000 to install an automated light and bell warning system at a level crossing. Installation costs for flashing lights, gates and bells are about $150,000. The total cost to eliminate grade crossings by contrast is positively immense.
To use an illustration, CN Rail's 534 kilometre, high density main line between Montreal and Toronto has 135 grade crossings with active warning systems as well as a large number of crossings with passive systems including public, private or farm grade crossings. The total cost of building grade separations on this line alone at an average cost of $8 million each would be in the order of
$1 billion. This figure does not include pedestrian crossings.
There are more than 24,000 public grade crossings in Canada, 8,000 of which are equipped with automatic protection devices such as flashing light signals, bells or gates. The balance is protected by standard cross-buck grade crossing warning signals. In addition, there are some 33,000 private or farm crossings which are for the most part unprotected.
Prevention of accidents at grade crossings requires action by motorists, railways, road authorities and the federal government. Therefore, an example of where responsibilities must be accepted is the establishment and maintenance of clear sight lines to enable drivers to see approaching trains. Although this measure is cost effective, it is sometimes difficult to get the responsible party to carry out line-of-sight clearance. While the railway responds relatively quickly to orders to clear brush along the rights of way, municipalities may resist a similar request to clear railway lines in their jurisdiction.
Under the Railway Safety Act, the Minister of Transport has extensive powers to improve grade crossing safety to help prevent accidents and to initiate remedial measures after an accident. Railway safety inspectors also have considerable discretionary powers to act in the interests of safety. It has used these powers to impose speed restrictions on both the railway and the road authority where it feels it is necessary to limit risk.
It has also required road and/or railway traffic to stop before proceeding through a crossing and, where a severe threat to safety exists, it has actually closed crossings. An exceedingly important component for safety at railway crossings rests with education.
Transport Canada contributes $150,000 a year to the Railway Association of Canada's Operation Lifesaver, a public education program that promotes safety at railway crossings. A recent survey done for Transport Canada has shown that the public is generally unaware of the inherent dangers at railway crossings. Much of Operation Lifesaver's public education campaign, therefore, will be directed at the areas targeted by the survey in coming years.
Transport Canada does not just talk about safety, it spends a fair amount of money. There is an $8.5 million program in place to improve grade crossing warning systems. The department pays up to 80 per cent of the total cost of railway crossing improvements and the

balance is provided by the railways, municipalities or provinces.
These improvements include the installation of automatic warning devices such as flashing lights and bells, the interconnection of devices to highway traffic signals, lighting, improvements to the road approaches, to track layout, clearing of line-of-sight and construction of a road or rail detour. There have to be choices made every year as to which projects proceed and which must wait.
The criteria used to assess these projects try to address this frankly tough process as fairly as possible. They consider the rail and road traffic densities and speed, school, public bus and truck traffic, dangerous commodities carried by road and rail, the angle and the view of the crossing. Tragically, they also have to consider the accident history as well as the number of train tracks and the type of train operation and all of the physical road factors such as lanes and grades.
Despite what might be implied by the motion before us, it is not as if there is not concrete action every year to improve crossing safety. The money spent annually through the Railway Crossing Improvement Program, namely $8.5 million, would pay for only two modest grade separations each year. Contrast that, if you will, with the more than 100 at-grade crossings that are actually improved each year with these resources.
The existing programs have contributed significantly to increased levels of safety at our railway crossings. During the last 10 years crossing accidents have been reduced significantly. In 1990 there were 386 railway crossing accidents. While one would want that figure to be even lower, it is down sharply from the 826 accidents which occurred in 1980.
Transport Canada's grade crossing improvement fund certainly appears to be the most effective means available to us at the moment to improve railway safety. Safety has been improved at thousands of crossings through this program. Funds are allocated on a priority basis to try as much as humanly possible to see that railway crossings are as safe as we can make them.
The sentiments expressed by my hon. friend opposite are laudable, but grade separation projects must be looked at in the context of delivering the best and safest

possible service to the widest population. For no other reason, I cannot support my hon. friend's motion as presented.
Mr. Speaker, I wonder if I might put a question to the hon. member and ask if she realizes that the grade crossing fund has been cancelled.

Mr. Speaker,
I am rather concerned. I understand the government House leader has been on television this morning saying that spending for infrastructure will do no good whatsoever. Nothing could be further from the truth. There are certainly several studies to show, in the United States context anyway, that spending in the public sector increases enormously the benefits to the private sector. If you think about it, it is rather obvious.
Whether it is railroads, bridges, highways, sewage treatment plants, hydroelectric generating capabilities, or whatever carried on through the public domain, it is rather obvious that if those things were not in place certainly the private sector would suffer enormously.
Imagine if the trucking industry was not able to transport the goods which it carries so well on our road system and had to transport over roads which were still gravel, for example. Saskatchewan is actually a pretty good example. Under the Conservative government in Saskatchewan, the roads deteriorated to an enormous extent. I can certainly understand why the municipalities and the trucking industry are saying that there has to be an improvement to the highways.
The point is that regardless of what segment of our society you look at, the private sector benefits enormously from the public expenditures in the whole realm of the infrastructure, whether it be municipal or on a national basis, or whether you are talking about sewer and water. This means that industries taking water from our rivers and streams for use in their plants may have to go to enormous lengths to treat the water so that it is pure enough for their use. This extra expenditure is certainly something which they have to take into account when they balance the bottom line. It is rather obvious that there is a benefit to the general public as well. When water is taken from the inlets to our public water

November 16, 1992
Private Members' Business
systems, the cleaner it is, the less expenditure we have to put forth as taxpayers in order to make it drinkable.
The Canadian Federation of Municipalities has done a tremendous amount of work on this. It should be commended for its efforts to raise the consciousness of the nation and hopefully draw the attention of the provincial and federal governments to the enormity of the problem facing the country. What we could term the situation we find ourselves in is a need for home improvement. It is rather obvious: If we never make any improvements to our homes, there comes a point where they deteriorate beyond a point where they are even habitable.
I would suggest that in the context of Canada being our home and the need for improvements, we have in many instances digressed, regressed and fallen to a point where some of our home is almost uninhabitable. That certainly would apply in so far as our rivers and streams are concerned. The South Saskatchewan River flows through the city of Saskatoon. There certainly is a tremendous amount of pollution getting into that river before it ever gets to the city.
I would like to add that in spite of the fact that the city of Saskatoon does have treatment plants for its sewage, there is certainly room for further treatment of that sewage before it goes back into the river for those who will be using it down stream from us. There is just no way that it is not obvious that if such action were to be taken that all citizens along our rivers and streams would certainly benefit from that expenditure.
The House is now back. We have been through a referendum where Canadians told us that the problem we are facing in this country for the most part is not some kind of a resolution to the esoteric way in which we view ourselves as a nation, but rather it is the nuts and bolts problem which we face and of course that is the economy. I do not think there is a member in this House who did not experience during the referendum the plea from the constituents to get on with what is really ailing this country and this economy and to do something about it.
It is just inconceivable how the government could say that there is no benefit from these kinds of expenditures. If we spend our resources on something which actually goes to create and put a better foundation under the
wealth of this nation, like an assessment of a city or a town, the more houses and things you have that are taxable within the jurisdiction, the broader the tax base is.
I assume the government is really saying that it is far better for the nation to spend money on paying off the interest on the debt, which seems to be rather unproductive, than it is to build roads and bridges which are productive and add enormously to the wealth of the nation.
I cannot for the life of me understand how it can possibly conceive that expending tremendous amounts of money on paying interest on the debt is adding to the wealth of the nation. It seems to me to be the opposite case. Most likely what is happening is that it is adding to the wealth of individuals in other nations because veiy few people to whom we pay that interest are in this country, and even those who are here are certainly doing the best they can to avoid contributing to the wealth of the nation.
The Canadian Federation of Municipalities is saying that we need access to clean water, as I have already alluded to, for a number of reasons, certainly not the least of which is the health of our citizens. That includes to no small degree the absolute necessity of water and sewage treatment plants on many Indian reserves which have been shown to be so lacking in those amenities, things we take for granted. As well, I have already alluded to the fact that they are saying we need better sewage treatment systems.
I cannot help but make a plea for the government to get away from the idea that it seems to be better to pay interest on money borrowed than it is to spend money on the infrastructure of this nation, which will put people to work. The money which is expended will go into the hands of people. In turn it will be spent in local communities and, to no small extent, will come back to the government in the form of taxation rather than out of the federal Treasury in the form of interest paid to banks and lending institutions that certainly will not return any. History shows that they have not returned any.
I congratulate the member from Regina who brought
forward this wonderful motion.

Mr. Speaker, I could not start without commenting on the remarks of the previous speaker. I hope his remarks were in humour when he urged the government not to pay interest on the national debt, not to pay interest on the money it borrows. I am sure those of us who invest in our country and buy Canada Savings Bonds would be somewhat discouraged if the NDP came into office and we found that it was not going to pay interest on Canada Savings Bonds as the member has just suggested.
Do not pay interest on the national debt, do not pay your bills; I guess that is NDP policy. We know from the last session of Parliament that the NDP's policy for the debt is simply to print more money. This is what its financial critic said in the last session: "Just print more money", as if it would not cost the taxpayer any money.
The NDP policy of not paying interest on the debt is somewhat amusing to those of us who buy Canada Savings Bonds or have pension plans, whether it be the teachers' pension plan, the nurses' pension plan or even the old railway workers' pension plan, those of us who buy government bonds or government monetary issues expecting to receive a return on that investment to reinvest in pension plans. speechtext:
Old fog-horn is bellowing down there, but the fact is the NDP member said seven or eight times during his remarks that we should not pay interest on the national debt.
Getting back to the subject at hand, I would agree that building up the national infrastructure is a laudable goal and one we can all support. My objective today is to convince members of the House that the motion of the
Private Members' Business
hon. member, the proposal he has made, is not a practical way or even a proper way of tackling this most important subject.
Let us look at the list of items that he proposes for our attention. He proposes improvements to the sewer and water treatment systems, road and bridge repair, and construction of grade separations at level railway crossings. I realize this is just a representative list but, even given that, the first thing that strikes me about it is that one of the items is clearly outside federal jurisdiction, a second is under active development, and a third, grade separations at railway level crossings, is already covered in a federal program.
Let me say I am not opposed to federal aid to other levels of government. I am as aware as the next person that all governments today are cash strapped. I am certainly not opposed to the use of scarce federal resources to achieve national goals that would otherwise be beyond the means of the responsible jurisdiction.
However, given that our means are limited, it surely is our duty as federal members to ensure that any such expenditure meets some recognized national goal. Otherwise we are just wasting valuable taxpayers' money.
Let us take a closer look at two of the hon. member's items. Sewer and water infrastructure is entirely a local matter. It is the most distant from federal jurisdiction of the items on the hon. member's list. Our first problem is deciding whether it is a matter for the federal government at all.
I do not for a moment deny that sewers and water treatment facilities are important, nor do I deny that they represent significant cost items for many Canadian municipalities. My objections are strictly practical. In today's tight economic climate the federal government must target its assistance to areas where it can make a difference nationally, and the federal government is committed to doing just that.
The hon. member proposes to build grade separations in place of level rail crossings. To put it in a nutshell grade separations are very expensive. They cost in the range of $3 million to $10 million each.
There is another kind of crossing, namely a protected level crossing with automated gates or lights, bells, or both. These projects cost in the range of $80,000 to

November 16, 1992
Government Orders
$150,000. Quite clearly money will stretch further for protected level crossings than for grade separations. This is not to say that grade separations are not worth it, but rather we have a responsibility to bring the best safety systems available to the greatest number of crossings.
Finally there is the hon. member's suggestion for a federal contribution to repairs to the nation's roads and bridges. As a matter of fact on this issue we are not entirely in disagreement. Indeed I am also of the opinion that highway upgrading and reconstruction is one area where the federal government could perhaps invest some money, but I am equally certain that if we are going to invest our resources at all it should be toward a national highway system.
I want to stress the importance of lasting economic value as a criterion for federal funding of infrastructure projects. Highways are an example of an area where carefully considered strategic application of federal money will pay lasting dividends for the country as a whole.
What are some of those dividends? How do better roads help the economy? There are gains in fuel efficiency, highway safety and travel times. Most important there would be greater efficiency in our distribution system in our domestic market. As is well known, highway policy is an area where federal government has been working in collaboration with the provinces toward a national policy.
As the House will recall, earlier this year first ministers directed their ministers of transport to consult with their ministers of finance and explore ways of proceeding with this work, remaining consistent with fiscal restraints. Considerable progress has been made in the discussions between transport ministers and finance ministers across the country with a notion of looking at a national infrastructure system, improvement of highways and reconstruction in Canada today.
To conclude, I support deliberate, carefully thought out, long-term national policies on specific infrastructure issues like highways.
Unfortunately this is not what the hon. member is asking us to support today and therefore I am unable to support the hon. member's resolution as it has been presented.

speechtext:
There are the Liberals calling for an election. That is all they talk about. The last thing the people I talk to want is an election. They want us to get on with the business of Parliament, and that is what we are doing.
I am pleased today to lead off second reading debate on Bill C-76 which implements certain provisions from the 1992 budget. The Minister of Finance, in the lead up to the budget of 1992, held consultations across Canada with people from all walks of life; labour, special interest groups such as the handicapped, the National Action Committee on the Status of Women, many of the trade associations, the financial institutions and so on. I participated with the Minister of Finance. These were tremendous consultation programs.
Government Orders
At the consultations where we had these groups together, a consensus was formed from these consultations. The concerns were responded to by the Minister of Finance in his budget of 1992.
Canadians told the minister that the government should take action to help get the recovery back on track and to help Canadian firms and workers become more competitive. They also told him they were concerned about the tax burden, about government spending and about the deficit.
The budget contained measures to boost the competitiveness of Canadian firms and workers. We announced tax support for the manufacturing and processing sector worth almost $2.3 billion over five years. The capital cost allowance rate was increased for manufacturing and processing machinery from 25 to 30 per cent.
The hon. member for Kingston and the Islands laughs at that. He thinks it is funny. I suggest that he talk to the manufacturers in Kingston to see if they appreciate this. It is exactly what they asked for in the pre-budget consultation. He sits there and makes fun of it. I cannot believe it.
This will help make Canada's manufacturing and processing sector, which directly accounts for about one-fifth of Canada's economy and jobs, more competitive. He does not understand that. Liberals do not understand competitiveness.
We also indicated that we are prepared to reduce the withholding tax on direct dividends paid to non-residents. This step, combined with the drop in the manufacturing and processing tax rate, will end the competitive disadvantage we face in attracting and keeping business in Canada.
The budget also announced further actions to reduce government expenditures in order to reduce federal taxes. We believe that cutting spending to cut taxes is economically productive. It reflects our confidence in the judgment of individual Canadians about how best to put their money to work in building a stronger, more competitive economy. Moreover, cutting spending will reinforce the government's deficit reduction effort, while at the same time allowing us to direct scarce resources to important national priorities.

November 16, 1992
Government Orders
The budget also provides tax relief through a number of measures to help Canadian families, students and students with disabilities.
In summary, the budget was fiscally prudent, socially responsive and economically sound. It reflects a realistic, balanced approach that will help pave the way for a return to sustained economic growth.
Bill C-76 will implement four measures contained in the budget. In order to help the government promote economic recovery, strengthen Canada's international competitiveness and further control its expenditures, the Small Businesses Loans Act, the Canada Student Loans Act, the Lobbyists Registration Act and the Salaries Act are all being amended.
First, I want to discuss the amendments to the Small Businesses Loans Act. Small businesses are a key to the healthy growth of Canada's economy. Reflecting their importance, our federal tax system offers significant support for small business. These recommendations came from the consultations with the small business sector leading up to the budget.
Small businesses enjoy a special reduced income tax rate of 12.8 per cent and that includes the 3 per cent surtax on the first $200,000 of business income. Canada's lifetime capital gains exemption provides an added incentive for individuals to invest in small business. Small businesses qualify for the most generous incentives for research and development in the G-7 countries, including a 35 per cent refundable federal tax credit instead of the general rate of 20 per cent. Over-all, Canada's federal tax system for small business is one of the most beneficial in the industrialized world. These measures provide Canadian small businesses with over $3 billion in support annually.
However, the government is aware that weathering the recession has drained the financial resources of many small businesses. As the economy moves into recovery, small businesses will need affordable financing to take advantage of the emerging opportunities for growth and help generate productive economic activity.
In order to provide greater assistance to small businesses and to help stimulate the process of recovery in
the economy, the Minister of Finance announced two measures in the budget to help small businesses.
A small business financing program, effective budget day, will help small businesses in financial difficulty, including farmers, to obtain loans at lower interest rates. Tax preferred small business financing bonds may be issued up until the end of this year and may have a maturity of up to five years. Therefore it can provide assistance well beyond the current year.
A complementary measure is contained in Bill C-76. The ceiling for loans to individual small businesses under the Small Businesses Loans Act will be double from $100,000 to $200,000. This change is in response to the increased financing needs of small business.
The Small Businesses Loans Act, first passed in 1961 by another Conservative administration, assists the private sector to obtain loans to establish, expand or modernize small businesses. The most recent amendment to the loan limit in 1980 established the ceiling at $100,000. As we all know, there have been considerable changes since that time, both in the purchasing power of the dollar and in the financing needs of small businesses.
The over-all consumer price index has roughly doubled since 1980. Doubling the Small Businesses Loans Act ceiling to $200,000 responds again to representations from the small business community and recognizes changes which have occurred over the past decade.
The current legislation authorizing the small business loans program will expire on March 31, 1993. The government will be introducing new legislation to extend the program. As part of this legislation, consideration is being given to modifying other program terms and conditions to take account of the concerns and needs expressed by smaller firms and the banking community.
Let me move now to a second important component of Bill C-76, the amendments to the Canada Student Loans Act.
The Canada student loan program was introduced in 1964 and makes financial help available to needy students pursuing studies at the post-secondary level. The program helps eligible students to meet the many costs involved in gaining a higher education. This is vitally important if Canada is to maintain and enhance its competitive position in a global economy. It is increasing-
November 16, 1992

ly clear that an educated and skilled workforce is a prerequisite for improved productivity and prosperity in today's competitive world. I think we all agree with that.
To help support an educated and competitive workforce, the program's current structure must be modernized. Left unattended, it may very well cease to be an effective tool for access to post-secondary education. Accordingly, to preserve this important national program and to ease its administration, the Canada Student Loans Act will be amended.
The Secretary of State, who administers the program, is negotiating new arrangements for student loans with financial institutions. The aim of the negotiation is to reduce the growing cost of the program and to improve its efficiency by asking the lenders to share in the risks and the cost of defaults. Saving are expected to provide scope for the needed improvements to the program, including the elimination of the 3 per cent fee, which is an administrative fee, and an increase in the weekly loan ceilings.
These important measures will be implemented following successful completion of the negotiations and passage of any necessary amendments to the Canada Student Loans Act. In the meantime there are some measures that we can take now.
As currently structured, the federal government guarantees loans made to full-time students by lending institutions. The government pays the interest costs while the students are at school and for six months after graduation. After completing their studies, the students must enter into a consolidated repayment agreement with their lending institutions. If a student fads to enter into a repayment agreement or fails to maintain payments, the federal guarantee is honoured. In other words, the federal government pays off the loan and the borrower's debt becomes due to the taxpayers of Canada.
The estimated interest cost the federal government will pay under the program in 1991-92 is almost $190 million. Payments in 1991-92 to lenders for loans that have gone into default are estimated at $175 million. Collection costs will total over $24 million.
Moreover, total defaults outstanding as of March 31, 1992 were $980 million-almost a billion dollars-owed to the taxpayers of this country.
Government Orders
Over the five-year period from 1985-86 to 1990-91, total program expenditures increased at a rate of over 9 per cent a year. It is essential that action be taken to ensure the continued financial viability of the Canada Student Loans Program.
Bill C-76 proposes to eliminate the six-month interest free period currently granted to full-time students upon their graduation. The budget had proposed this for the 1992-93 loan year, but following consultations with the financial institutions, this measure will now be effective for the loan year beginning August 1, 1993. This will coincide with planned improvements to the program and will give financial institutions the time required to implement the necessary adjustments to their systems.
It is important to remember that students can continue to benefit from Canada student loans, interest free, for the entire time they are in school. They will also continue to have up to six months after leaving school to make repayment arrangements with their lenders. However, during this period, interest on their loans will accrue. Borrowers in repayment will continue to be eligible for up to 18 months of interest relief in the event that they are encountering financial hardship in repaying their loans.
Through Bill C-76, the government is also moving to ease the administration of the Canada Student Loans Program. In future the necessary forms used in the program will be determined by the Secretary of State rather than the Governor in Council, as is the present practice. Making the forms an administrative matter and not part of regulations will provide better scope for planning and implementing administrative changes and co-ordinating these changes with the lenders and the provinces.
Bill C-76 also proposes to update the alternative payment formula which is designed to compensate provinces choosing to establish their own student loan programs as an alternative to participating in the Canada Student Loans Program.
The changes in Bill C-76 will ensure that the alternative payments to provinces that might opt out of the program reflect more accurately spending in the province on outstanding Canada student loans. In addition, a

The federal government wants the Canada Student Loans Program to remain as widely available across the country as humanly possible. It is a national program and we want to keep it that way. Consistent with our policies of fiscal restraint and responsible management, the Minister of Finance indicated in the budget that the government would strengthen its cost recovery performance. To this end, Bill C-76 proposes to amend the Lobbyists Registration Act. It is our view that the lobbyists registration program should be operated on a cost recovery basis.
Specifically the government proposes to amend the fee-setting regulation to allow the Govemor-in-Council to charge lobbyists a registration fee when registering under the act. The fee will be determined in consultation with the private sector.
Fees owing will also be made a debt to the Crown so that the Crown may sue in the civil courts to recover unpaid fees. To further encourage compliance, the current penalty avoidance incentives which exist to encourage compliance with the act will be extended to the registration fees.
Finally, Bill C-76 amends the Salaries Act. Last year the government froze ministerial, parliamentary and Public Service pay. We believe that in a period of national economic hardship, ministers of the Crown, including the Prime Minister, should further contribute to the restraint effort by cutting back their ministerial salaries. To meet this commitment, and to further assist the government to reduce its expenditures, the ministerial salaries of the Prime Minister and all ministers will be reduced by 5 per cent effective this past April 1.
In closing, I want to reiterate that the February budget was designed in response to what the government heard from Canadians in all parts of the country. The measures contained in this bill are an integral part of that response. They will help the government to live within the taxpayers' means and to create the conditions for recovery, strong growth and a more competitive economy.

speakerposition: Deputy Whip of the Liberal Party
subtopic: BUDGET IMPLEMENTATION (FISCAL MEASURES) ACT, 1992 MEASURE TO AMEND
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I stand today to speak to Bill C-76 which is a budget implementation measure of the budget which was tabled last February.
Canadians all know that this government's fiscal measures are not working. There is a-total lack of trust. We are into a major recession. We can even call it a depression. We are still implementing measures that were brought forward in the budget of February 1992. We know today that the finance minister is preparing to bring forward either an economic statement or a mini budget shortly. We also know that the Prime Minister has said that his government has made mistakes. We asked the government when it was going to bring forward some new measures that would do something for the Canadian economy. Yes, the government has made mistakes and we can all feel it. Just go out on the streets and everyone will tell you that there are no jobs. From small business to big business to students, every Canadian is worried as to where we are going next.
This government does not know where it wants to go and it does not know how to get there. I ask the government to please do whatever it can to start making some concrete investments in Canadians. That is what we need. Canadians need to be able to constructively contribute to this country. It is absolutely impossible to do this under what this government has done.
The government has tried to tell people that it was responsible when it has done nothing. It had a prosperity initiative that cost $24 million which told us things we already knew. The government has told us that it has done polling. It spends millions of dollars every week on polling. It should know by now that it is not the polling that is going to do things for Canadians. It is what it is going to do about the results that it is hearing. It is impossible for us to continue in the same light that we have been continuing for the last eight years.
When the Prime Minister was first elected and first became the Prime Minister he said: "Watch me. You will not recognize this country when I am through with it". Boy, was he right. The problem is that we do not want to see our country the way it is right now. We want some
Bill C-76 purports to do many things. I listened to the ministers and I know they mean well, but they do not know what they are doing.
Let us talk about Canada student loans. Yes, it is important that students be able to get loans. It is essential because right now, most students were not able to get a summer job to help pay their way. Most of them are not able to get a large enough loan to keep on going. The problems that the students have right now are horrendous. However we go on preaching that we have to invest in our young people. Yes, we have to invest in our young people, but we have to help them along and we have to do more to help them.
When a student gets a Canada student loan it is not because he is rich or because he has the money. It is because he needs the help. There is no interest on the loan while he is a full-time student in school, but this government now says that as soon as he finishes his course there is no more interest-free period. From that day on the interest starts accumulating. That is fine if the student is able to get a job, but how many students have been able to get a job the day after they graduate? Very, very few. Those who do have part-time work which does not pay very much and have a great deal of difficulty of coping with what is happening to them.
This government in the last budget said: "Well, we have to do something about the defaults on Canada's student loans". That sounds like a good reason to collect from those who are not paying, especially from those who were able to get good jobs because of their educa-* tion. They should pay for their loans. I agree with that. However, one of the things that has been happening is that we have been terrorizing young people who have not been able to get jobs.
I have been in my riding and I cannot begin to tell you the number of people who have come to see me, crying, because some collection agency has been terrorizing them in their homes. I had one woman come to my office a week ago. She is the mother of a 26-year old who is on welfare. The collection agency found out where she lived, telephoned her and verbally abused this lady, laughed at her and told her: "Get a mortgage on your

November 16, 1992
Government Orders
house. Pay off your son's loan". This is a 26-year old who is on welfare and who cannot get a job.
The mother does not own her own home. She came to me crying and asking: "Why are they doing this to me?" The collection agency said: "We can call you three times a day if we want to". When she came to see me I called the collection agency and asked: "Why are you terrorizing the mother of a 26-year old? She does not have any money. The son does not have any money. What are you doing? You have no right to terrorize the parent of a 26-year old".
First of all, I had a hard time getting the person at the collection agency to identify what company they were working for. They were demanding that the parents pay off the loan in full for the student. The parents did not have the money. The way these collection people treated me when I simply asked what company they worked for is unbelievable. Finally, after I spoke to them for a while, they agreed that they should not be terrorizing the parent of the 26-year old, that they should speak to him directly. However, what do you do when a young man is living on welfare? How can he make payments on a loan? I do not know. I know how little they get on welfare.
A young woman came to see me, again the same thing. She wanted to make payments but the collection agency was not giving her any option. They said: "You have to pay the balance in full". But when I called they said: "Well, no". These are just collection tactics.
Do we do the same thing with the Reichmann brothers when they default on a loan? Do we terrorize them? Are we telling them that their credit is finished?
On Friday another young man came to see me. He was very frightened. He said: "I do not have a job. I do not mind making payments but they do not want payments. They want the full amount. They told me that if I did not pay off the full amount, and I do not have the money to do that, they would garnishee my wages and I would never get another job because what employer would hire me if I owed this amount of money". I am shocked at the kind of treatment our young people are getting. This is disastrous. There is no need to go after the poorest of the poor that way. If they have jobs, by all means make
sure they pay. However, if they do not have jobs, what can you do? How discouraging it must be for these young people.
A lot of the reasons they do not have jobs is because of this government's policies. It is frightening to think that this government has lost total control, absolute total control of the economy. It is absolutely shameful.
It talks about investing in our future and investing in our young people. It has cut back on transfer payments for education, therefore tuition fees are increasing. How do you expect the poorest of the poor to cope with increased tuition fees and GST on books? They have to pay it. They do not have any choice. How do you expect them to cope with these kinds of things?
This particular bill does not even tell us whether they will be able to apply for interest relief. In the past, if after the first six months after graduation they did not have a job, they could apply for interest relief. I would like to find out if they can continue to apply for interest relief. Already we have passed the 3 per cent surcharge. Do people out there realize that students have to pay the 3 per cent in cash before they actually get the loan? If you need a loan to go to school where are you going to get the 3 per cent to pay for it in advance? You will have to borrow somewhere else so that when you get your loan you can pay it back. What kind of nonsense is that?
We talk about tax relief. I am pleased that during the last budget the government did bring in some measures that would offer tax relief. That is great if you have parents who can afford to pay for you and they can get the tax relief. What about the thousands of young people who do not have parents that can afford to pay for them? What about them? What good is giving them tax relief if they do not have any income? Any kind of measure that saves you income tax money does not work if you do not pay income tax already.
Right now I am very worried about what this is going to do. I know it is a minor thing to say that we are going to start charging interest from the day they graduate. In the scheme of things the Conservatives can say: After all, the government has lent them the money. What can we tell those young people about a job?
November 16, 1992

If a person has a job and gets laid off under unemployment insurance he or she has been able to get training funds. Yes, that has been good. It means that not only is their tuition fee covered but also they get unemployment insurance while they are in training, although I am told that those funds have run out also.
In a sense these people have a greater advantage than other young people who have chosen to get their education before going out into the workforce. They have no retraining advantage. They do not even have any kind of a hope, most of them, of getting a job. I cannot tell the House the numbers of students that have been to my office with masters degrees, with economics degrees, with all kinds of education degrees that have been unable to find jobs.
It is a signal of a country in crisis when our young people have so little hope. Then we do something to change our policy. I know that this government is thinking about doing that, but it needs to do it today, not three weeks from now, not four weeks from now. The government needed to do it two years ago, but better late than never.
The first thing the government should do is admit that it has failed. It has already admitted that. It has failed. As soon as it realizes that, it should not wait two or three weeks. It should not wait one week. It should come out right away with some measure to invest in people.
I know that my Conservative friends across the way are going to say: "That is just the Liberals and their policy of spend, spend, spend". I tell them that investing in people is not a waste of money. A person who sits at home on welfare and is discouraged consumes as much money as the one who goes out and works at something and leaves something behind, be it in municipal infrastructure, sewer, water projects, whatever.
Would it not be better to have brought forward something in this budget concerning students to say that those students who have graduated, who have been unable to get jobs in order to start paying back their student loans, could do some community work and perhaps get credits against the interest or against their loans?
I believe that the president-elect of the United States has actually proposed something like this. Perhaps this
Government Orders
government that has in the past always followed what the Americans do might consider this. Do members opposite not think it would be a good idea?
Think of a young person who is without work and living on welfare. How much better would such people feel about themselves if they were actually contributing something and at the same time keeping the collector on their student loans off their backs while they are waiting to find a job. Then they would be investing their time and would actually be doing something more constructive than sitting at home, living on welfare and worrying about where they are going to go next.
These are positive things that we can do for our students. They are very positive. We have to consider doing things for our students. We have to offer them the opportunity to gain some kind of experience, be it community work and perhaps some relief from their student loans or again just working physically at some infrastructure programs where there will actually be something left after they finish, such as a sewer built. All these things are going to have to be done. If they are not done this year they will have to be done next year.
It is important we consider the kinds of things that can be done and the way we direct our money. Perhaps we can redirect the money this government has been spending on polling. Every department does its own polling constantly. Can you imagine the millions of dollars that have gone into all of these polls? If the government redirected some of the advertising money or other misspent money, it would go a very long way toward creating the kinds of jobs that will leave something behind next year and the year after. I think it is very important.
We must remember there are very few dollars but we must use them in concrete ways that will help the people in the long term, not just in the short term. Doing nothing means the unemployed go from unemployment insurance to welfare. On welfare they get money, and it costs the government money, but there is nothing left. They can eat and sit at home, but imagine how much better it will be when they are able to go out and actually do something. They will feel much better and it will be

November 16, 1992
Government Orders
much better for the country. They get money to live at that point because they are paid for work they have done.
There are many things having to do with students that are shameful in a country that values education, that values the future as we are purported to do. The fact that so many of our people are unemployed is absolutely the most shameful thing that we face every day as parliamentarians. That is the first thing we should concentrate on, getting those young people to be productive members of our society. We should be giving them the best education possible, making it easier for them to go to school and get that education rather than making it harder. We should be making it better for them so they do not have to worry about where their next meal is coming from.
One of the most shameful things I have learned is that there are food banks at every major school in the country pretty well and there is a tremendous demand at the food banks at the universities. Does that not tell you that many of our students are the poorest of the poor? They have to have food banks because these young people do not know where they are going to get their next meal. Is that not shameful in a country that wants its young people to be the best educated? How can they learn if they have empty bellies? There are a few jobs but they are few and far between. We must do something far more productive and far more decisive than these kinds of measures. Obviously that is why the finance minister is planning to bring out an economic statement and a mini budget.
There are four major parts to this particular bill, and one of them is the increase in the small business development loan ceiling. There will be an amendment to the Small Businesses Loans Act which increases the individual loan amount from $100,000 to $200,000. That is a good measure.
However, many small businesses have asked that the ceiling be made higher because not all financial institutions will deal with an amount of $200,000. They would prefer to have more institutions involved, but obviously that is something we can ask the government to consider while we are studying this bill in committee. I do not know if it would be agreeable to this kind of an
amendment. Small businesses are the backbone of our economy and they have been extremely hard hit.
We talked about the students. We might as well talk about the small business people in the same way. They have borne the brunt of a lot of the costs of the GST. The smaller they are, the more difficult it has been for them to survive, to do the work associated with many of the changes that have come about due to this government's economic and fiscal policies. It is extremely important that we allow this kind of a ceiling because obviously if you are in big trouble the odds of getting a larger loan are not very good.
We also have to talk to bankers. The Federal Business Development Bank has perhaps to reconsider its mandate. It has now become just an ordinary bank. It will lend money the same way an ordinary bank will lend money. If the business is slightly risky it does not look at it.
Where does a small business person go when he or she is in financial trouble or when he or she needs some kind of bridge financing? It is not easy because these are tough times. People have not been making profits. They do not have a lot of collateral to offer for loans.
When there is no collateral more often than not banks will not look at you. They will not offer you a loan if you say you are going to work hard and make this happen. They are going to offer you a loan if you have something with which you can back up your loan, your personal home, or whatever investments you may have.
If you are in trouble as a small business person, you have already given your house and any other investments you might have had are long gone and your house is up as collateral. How do you increase the amounts you have?
It is especially important that this government come up with some policy to help small businesses in trouble, that the tightening up not occur. I know the banks are tiying their best but as financial institutions they have to show a profit to their shareholders. It very important that some scheme be worked out between the government and the banking institutions in order to allow the kinds of loans, the kinds of incentives for small businesses because they are the ones that create the jobs. They are the only way at this point that we have of really pulling ourselves out of this recession.
November 16, 1992

If we encourage our small business sector then we will be better off. We know that. Hopefully the small business people in our country, in our cities and in our towns will continue to work on. They work extremely long hours. If you have ever been in any kind of a small business usually it is owner operated. In hard times the owner works longer and longer hours under more stressful conditions. He cannot afford to hire people. Often they suffer from burnout.
Would it not be so much better if the owners could afford to hire a few people to help them, if there were some way that they could feel secure enough in their business to hire these young people who are without work. Then we have a chance.
I am asking this government to make sure that these kinds of policies are put in place so that our small business sector can grow and create jobs the way they have done in the past and the way they must continue to help us.
One of the other parts of this bill is the amendments to the Lobbyists Registration Act. The government is saying that if it wants anything having to do with these lobbyists, it is that the whole cost be recovered. At first glance that sounds like a very good idea. However, one of the things that worries me is whether this will deny access to those people who need to lobby the government but have no money.
Let us make sure that we do not cut out all of the poorer people from getting through to government. The rich people and the rich lobbyists can always find a way around it, but in these hard times we must always be very much in touch with the poorer people so that the policies that are brought forward by this government can be talked about by these lobbyists who represent groups that do not have the kinds of dollars that perhaps some of the other ones have. Under the terms of the Lobbyists Registration Act, passed by Parliament in 1988, the statute would have to be reviewed on the third anniversary of the enactment. The third anniversary of the enactment was September 30, and as the House was adjourned for the referendum campaign the government put off the resumption of Parliament and the requirement to strike a committee.
Government Orders
This committee, which should be struck now, would have one year to report back to the House to present its findings and any recommendations for amendments to the Lobbyists Registration Act. This would be an opportunity to begin dealing constructively with the central issues in Canadian democracy: the relationship of the government to its people and how public policy is formed.
Will the mandate of this parliamentary committee be broadened to include the examination of how public policy advocacy is conducted generally in Canada including the use of advocacy advertising, coalition building, grassroots campaigns, public opinion polling, paid lobbyists, and the relative inequities between those few elements of society that can afford to hire highly skilled advocates and those many who cannot?
These are things that must be studied. We know that this piece of legislation will be passed, as this government does have a majority, but we ask that it consider these requests when it strikes the committee. It is extremely important for all Canadians.
The last one is an amendment to the Salaries Act which, effective April 1, 1992, cut the salaries of the Prime Minister, ministers and ministers of state by 5 per cent. That is good. Obviously when you freeze everybody else's salaries you must somehow lead the way and show that you are also prepared to tighten your belt. The only question is whether 5 per cent was enough. That can be debated. I was pleased to see the government do this.
On the other hand, we hear that the Prime Minister is thinking of reducing his cabinet. Let us remind all Canadians that since the Conservatives took office they have had the biggest cabinet ever. When the Liberals were in office the cabinet was not as large as it is now. Perhaps if back in 1984 the Conservatives had done a little bit more thinking rather than just talking they might have saved us millions of dollars by keeping it on the slimmer side, even slimmer than that of the Liberals. I have no objections to that.
That is a question that must be asked.
I know that this government is planning to bring forward some new initiatives. I look forward to hearing them because I, as well as most Canadians, do not believe that this government knows where it is going or

Government Orders
has any idea what to do. This government is in total disarray. Canadians no longer trust this government. For all Canadians the sooner it resigns the better.

subtopic: BUDGET IMPLEMENTATION (FISCAL MEASURES) ACT, 1992 MEASURE TO AMEND
speechtext:
It is my pleasure today to speak on the matter of Bill C-76, the omnibus tax or budget bill that is before the House today.
This bill is one that tags a number of different loose ends. It introduces some things that are probably a step in the right direction, and some things that are perhaps questionable.
The bill itself is essentially divided into four parts. The first deals with the Canada Student Loans Act and makes some necessary changes and some changes that are perhaps questionable. The second deals with the Lobbyists Registration Act and is once again a dichotomy. Some parts are essential and some parts are perhaps questionable with respect to some of the fine tuning of the bill. The third part reduces salaries of ministers and the Prime Minister by 5 per cent. I will have some comment on that a little bit later. The fourth part increases the Small Businesses Loans Act limit from $100,000 to $200,000.
First, allow me to give an overview before I speak specifically about these parts of the bill. If we examined the budget overall-and I am not going to speak at great length about the budget because I have had my kick at the cat as many others in the House have had. However, since this is set up in the budget it is relevant to examine the direction that this government has taken over the last few years and where we are at the present time.
Part of the reason I am bringing this up is because I read a recent statement by the Prime Minister in which he spoke about the recession and the depth of the recession. He said, essentially, that he did not realize how deep the recession would go, that some of the economists of the finance department had not recognized the difficulties and that possibly he would have changed some of the government's direction.

subtopic: BUDGET IMPLEMENTATION (FISCAL MEASURES) ACT, 1992 MEASURE TO AMEND
